    prefac  at iisd we frequently hear the complaint that there is both  wealth and  dearth of information about sustainable development no shortage   writing on the subject, but difficulty in knowing what to read and where   find it. the topic is complex, global, and still not firmly categorized in th  minds of librarians, booksellers, and audio-visual distributors. this firs  edition of sourcebook on sustainable development attempts to sor  through this bounty and give the reader  useable window on both th  practical and intellectual side of sustainable development. we found three trends while assembling our directory. while the better known international institutions concerned with th  environment, development, and human welfare are issuing an importan  body of work on sustainable development, another entire outlook on th  subject is flowing upwards from grassroots organizations and writers   both the industrialized and the developing world. this valuabl  information is not always readily available, and indeed, this book to som  extent reflects that scarcity. secondly, computer networking has become an extremely importan  means of communicating opinions, news, and debate on sustainabl  development. anyone researching the subject would be remiss not to ta  into the electronic web of knowledge that now encircles the world. writin  never destined to be published in the conventional sense resides on dat  bases, bulletin boards, and in the computers of individuals who might no  otherwise have an opportunity to speak to the rest of the world. and finally, we, realize that publishing references on sustainabl  development is like supervising  garden planted by someone else. the field is both extraordinarily productive and frustratingly unpredictable. based on our own work at iisd, we gathered obvious sources and som  not so obvious, with the understanding that much more would follo  after the sourcebook was printed, bound, and circulated, especially in th  period following the earth summit. it is our expectation that the project can be  long-term collaboration; an evolving directory, on paper and in electronic appendix  what is compute  communications? computer communications has been evolving during th  past 20 years and has now reached the point where it   gaining widespread recognition as  cost-effective means   communication, with distinct advantages over the mor  traditional methods of regular mail, telephone and fax. using this technology, people are able to exchange informa- tion stored on computers, quickly and inexpensively, vi  telephone lines. there are three main kinds of computer communications: -mail (electronic mail), computer conferencing, and onlin  databases. using -mail, people are able to send messages to eithe  one or several individuals simultaneously, with deliver  time ranging from  few minutes to  few hours, dependin  on the service used. for sharing of information among many dozens   hundreds of members of  workteam or interest group, computer conferencing is useful. participants can read an  respond to messages at their leisure, over  period of weeks, months, or even years. (on some networks, mailing list  take the place of conferences.) online databases are much more structured since the infor- mation base is maintained by  single organization. user  search for specific items via keywords. databases do no  offer interactive, interpersonal communications. what are the advantages   computer communications? computer networks save time and resources. letters don  have to be printed out on paper, placed into envelope  (which also saves on trees) and then physically transporte  over long distances to their destination. they can be sen  directly to the recipients online address in  matter   minutes, to virtually any address. and the messages don  have to be sent one at  time to several people;  singl  message can be sent to dozens of correspondents simulta- neously. computer conferences and mailing lists allow larg  numbers of people residing in  number of different loca- tions, even across several continents, to have ongoin  discussions and share information with each other, when - ever they have the time. often the messages remain on th  network to provide an easily referenced record of grou  interactions. policy and planning documents, proposals,-mail messages can be sent from your computer to any fa  or telex machine, using the resources of some network  (such as the apc networks), thus eliminating the need fo  the occasional sender to buy  fax or telex. like -mail,  single message can be sent to many recipients at the sam  time. -mail can be much more reliable and cost-effective tha  telephone calls or faxes, especially in the third world wher  the telecommunications infrastructure is very poor. unlik  fax, the modem links have built-in error correction and ca  be set up to continually try to connect until  link is estab- lished, without human involvement.  few minutes of searching through an online database ca  save hours or days of painstaking research in  library, an  has  better chance of producing the information you need. perhaps most importantly, computer networks offer peopl  the opportunity to share the fellowship of others with simi- lar interests and concerns, no matter where they live. small, dispersed groups of individuals with  particular visio  today can evolve into  thriving community of people work- ing together to make that vision  reality. what are computer networks? computer networks have become the main vehicle fo  computerized information exchange.  computer networ  is generally thought of as an integrated system of hos  computers, each of which has  number of people usin  them, linked together over telecommunication line  through the use of  particular kind of software. suc  networks, particularly the large ones with  great man  computers linked to each other, have generally bee  defined by the type of software used by the host computer  making up the network. hosts on the internet, for example, link up with software called tcpip, while uucp networ  computers use uucp software to transfer data. in order for people to belong to  particular network, whether that network is  single, local, stand-alone bb  (bulletin board system), or an internationally-distribute  network with thousands of linked host computers, the  must have an account on one of the network computers. they can then use  modem  device allowing thei  computer to send and receive data over the telephone   connect to their account on that particular host computer, in order to use its facilities. it is possible for individuals   belong to several networks, though each network has differ- ent policies concerning who may have access.method of group interaction.research reports, papers, budgets, meeting schedules an  agendas are all easily planned and produced using this 91 in            in           su          de          there are several kinds of networks: npacket switching networks arecommon data carriers tha  route data from one computer to another, nationally an  internationally. usually  monopoly operated by  coun- trys telephone company, these networks are mostly use  by the business community for transmitting financial an  accounting data. increasingly though, they are used   individuals as  relatively inexpensive method to connec  to  network host computer over long distances. they ar  sometimes called.25 networks after the type of routin  software they use. some examples are: datapac in cana- da, sprintnet in the us, and renpac in brazil. ncommercial networks are generally of three types: -mail, database gateways, and information utilities. -mai  services, such as dialcom in england, allow electroni  message delivery to another user with an account on tha  system. database gateways, such as inet 2000 in canada, provide online access to several database vendors, such   dialog in the us. information utilities, such as minitel   france, offer most computer communications services, but are oriented toward the commercial vending of infor- mation and online services such as flight reservations an  bank-at-home operations. nbbs networks are amalgamations of local bulletin boar  systems (bbss). these local bbss, numbering in th  hundreds in most large cities in the north, and havin  some -mail and conferencing capabilities, were set up   hobbyists for the exchange of software programs. the largest example of such  network is fidonet, which ha  worldwide coverage. nresearch networks are the largest kinds of networks, having been created primarily by computer communica- tion scientists for the purpose of facilitating scientifi  research. they are non-commercial in nature and ofte  have restrictions placed on who is able to use them. the largest ones, including internet, bitnet, an  uucpusenet, have thousands of hosts, and millions   users around the world. nnot-for-profit social change networks are those that lin  national and regional networks serving people and organi- zations actively trying to improve social and environmen- tal conditions. offering -mail, computer conferencing, and, increasingly, online databases, they facilitat  communication on issues such as peace, environment, social justice, international development, health, an  education. examples include alternex in brazil and pega- sus in australia.who has access? for the most part, each network has its own policies regard- ing access to accounts on the system. packet switching an  commercial networks are open to anyone who can pay fo  the services. bbs networks are mostly free of charge (thoug  the ones with the better services often require fees) an  allow anyone to join. research networks usually restric  access to academics and research personnel. the socia  change networks, while open to all, generally cater   progressive, grassroots organizations. how much does it cost? the cost to the users of  network depends on the policies   the network administrations. research networks and loca  bbss usually dont charge users (the research institution   the bbs operator picks up the tab on everyones behalf), though they often place restrictions on service usage. packe  switching networks, whose prices are mostly fixed by th  government in consultation with the telephone company, usually charge between usd5hour and usd30hou  depending on the country.  special account called an nu  (network user identifier), which is required in some coun- tries, can sometimes cost several hundred dollars. commer- cial and social change networks charges vary, but an aver - age user of -mail and conferencing can expect to spen  less than usd50
